properties.headline: Flood Warning issued January 7 at 5:42PM PST until January 10 at 4:02AM PST by NWS Seattle WA
properties.description:
...The Flood Warning has ended for the following rivers in
Washington...

Samish River At Burlington affecting Skagit County
North Fork Stillaguamish River Near Arlington affecting Snohomish
County
Skykomish River Near Gold Bar affecting Snohomish County
Tolt River Above Carnation affecting King County
Newaukum River Near Chehalis affecting Lewis County

...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in
Washington...

Satsop River Near Satsop affecting Grays Harbor County
Snohomish River At Snohomish affecting Snohomish County
Snoqualmie River Near Snoqualmie Falls affecting King County
Snoqualmie River Near Carnation affecting King County
Skookumchuck River Near Bucoda affecting Thurston County
Chehalis River Above Grand Mound affecting Grays Harbor and Thurston
Counties
Chehalis River At Porter affecting Grays Harbor County
Bogachiel River Near La Push affecting Clallam County
Skokomish River At Potlatch affecting Mason County
Stillaguamish River At Arlington affecting Snohomish County


Some rivers have crested and flooding has ended while others are
still rising or still above flood stage. Rain coming in overnight
could keep some river levels from falling or even cause additional
rises, but should not add any new flooding. Here is the latest river
forecast updates.

The Flood Warning continues for
The Chehalis River At Porter
* Until late Thursday night.
* At  4:45 PM Tuesday the stage was 48.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 48.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue to rise and crest near 48.8 feet
around 4 PM Wednesday. The river will fall below flood stage
Thursday evening.
* Impact...At 48.0 feet, the Chehalis River in Grays Harbor will flood
low pasture lands and some roads. High tidal levels at Aberdeen
will worsen flooding along the lower reaches.
properties.instruction:
Do not drive cars...vans...or trucks through flooded areas...this is
the cause of most flood related deaths in Washington. Be alert for
rapid changes and monitor developments by listening to NOAA Weather
radio or other local media.
